<!DOCTYPE html><html lang="en"><head><meta charset="utf-8"><meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width,initial-scale=1,maximum-scale=5,minimum-scale=1,user-scalable=yes"><title>The Return To The Office: Best Practices For Helping Employees Feel Safe</title><script type="text/javascript" src="https://sdk.sharethrough.com/gc.js" data-str-disable-tracking="true" async></script><script>window["forbes"] = window["forbes"] || {}; window["forbes"]["isEurope"] = false</script><script>window["forbes"]["isChina"] = false</script><script>window["forbes"]["isUsDpa"] = false</script><script>window["forbes"]["isUs"] = true</script><script type="text/javascript">var templateType = "standard";
window.forbes = window.forbes || {};
window.forbes.isAdvisor = templateType === 'advisor';// this file is external 3rd party code to initiate header prebidding which comes directly from Medianet
// https://forbesmedia.atlassian.net/browse/ADSS-77
/* eslint-disable no-underscore-dangle, camelcase */
window._mNHandle = window._mNHandle || {};
window._mNHandle.queue = window._mNHandle.queue || [];
window.medianet_versionId = '3121199';
window.medianet_chnm = '';
window.medianet_chnm2 = '';
window.forbes = window.forbes || {};
window.forbes.fastFetchMedianet = true;

(() => {
	const loadScript = (tagSrc) => {
		const scriptTag = document.createElement('script');
		const placeTag = document.getElementsByTagName('script')[0];
		scriptTag.type = 'text/javascript';
		scriptTag.async = true;
		scriptTag.src = tagSrc;
		placeTag.parentNode.insertBefore(scriptTag, placeTag);
	};

	const loadMedianetManagePrebid = (isMobile) => {
		window.mnjs = window.mnjs || {
			customerId: isMobile ? '8CU243I76' : '8CU4ZAPFY',
			domain: window.location.hostname,
			version: 1.0,
		};
		/* eslint-disable prefer-template */
		const mnjsEndpoint = 'https://warp.media.net/js/tags/clientag.js?'
			+ 'cid=' + window.mnjs.customerId
			+ '&dn=' + window.mnjs.domain
			+ '&version=' + window.mnjs.version;
		loadScript(mnjsEndpoint);
	};

	/**
	 * gets user agent from navigator info
	 * @param {String} ua user agent from navigator
	 * @param {String} isMobileAndroid for android devices
	 * @param {String} isMobileWindows for windows phone devices
	 * @returns a string representing the user agent
	 */
	const getIsMobile = (ua, isMobileAndroid, isMobileWindows) => ua.match(/iP(hone|od)/i)
		|| ua.match(/iPod/i)
		|| ua.match(/BlackBerry/i)
		|| isMobileAndroid
		|| isMobileWindows;

	const ua = navigator.userAgent;
	const isMobileAndroid = ua.match(/Android/i) && ua.match(/Mobile/i);
	const isMobileWindows = ua.match(/Nokia|NOKIA/i) && ua.match(/Symbian|Windows Phone/i);
	const isMobile = getIsMobile(ua, isMobileAndroid, isMobileWindows);

	const loadMedianetHeaderBidding = () => {
		if (window.forbes.isAdvisor) {
			loadScript('https://contextual.media.net/bidexchange.js?cid=8CU25AH4U');
		} else {
			loadMedianetManagePrebid(isMobile);
		}
	};

	const loadMedianetAd = () => {
		const { lastCustomData } = window.forbes;
		// mnet ad logic here https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1kI9tKGs1jhu9j4J-RqFKz-TRhxiH3lY-He62on7qkLg/edit#gid=917757669
		const brandVoice = ((lastCustomData?.contribType && lastCustomData.contribType === 'AdVoice') || (lastCustomData?.author && lastCustomData.author === 'AdVoice'));
		const pageType = window.forbes['simple-site']?.adZone;
		const unpaidContribType = (pageType === 'contribhome' && !brandVoice);
		// mnet exists on legacy paid content types
		const legacyPaidContent = lastCustomData['Paid Content'] && !brandVoice;
		// this returns a string 'true' or 'false'
		const premiumProfile = window.forbes['simple-site']?.tracking?.premiumProfiles;
		const isChanSec = ['channel', 'section'].includes(pageType);
		const isBasicProfile = pageType === 'profile' && (premiumProfile === 'false');
		const isHome = window.mnjs?.channel?.includes('home');
		const isTopics = window.location.pathname.includes('/topics/');
		// only load the mnet ad where it's rendered
		// search and article on both DT and mobile (not vetted, paid content or premium)
		const search = window.location.pathname.includes('search');
		const article = (!brandVoice && (['live', 'topline', 'standard', 'advisor', 'finds'].includes(window.templateType) || pageType.includes('article/standard') || pageType.includes('article-blue/standard'))) || pageType.includes('masthead') || legacyPaidContent;
		// mobile specific to home, video page, video standalone, unpaid contrib, unpaid profile, and chansec
		const requireMobileMnet = isMobile && !brandVoice && ((window.location.pathname.includes('video') || unpaidContribType || isChanSec || isBasicProfile || isHome || legacyPaidContent || isTopics));
		if (search || article || requireMobileMnet) {
			loadScript('https://contextual.media.net/dmedianet.js?cid=8CU2T3HV4&https=1');
		}
	};

	/**
	 * check if the _swb_consent_ cookie is loaded
	 * @Todo make the ketch checks on the window so we can call them from there and make sure we dont
	 * lose time in the proccess
	 * we added ketch check to make sure we don't load medianet if the user is in the EU or China
	 * adding the checks here is a temporary solution.
	 * @returns boolean that represents if the cookie is loaded or not
	 */
	const checkConsentCookieLoaded = () => !!document.cookie.match(/_swb_consent_=/);

	/**
	 * get the _swb_consent_ cookie and url decode it to get it ready for parseing
	 * @returns String that has the ketch cookie value
	 */
	function getSwbCookieValue() {
		let cookieValue = false;
		if (!checkConsentCookieLoaded()) {
			return cookieValue;
		}

		const ketchCookieName = '_swb_consent_=';
		document.cookie.split(';').forEach((cookie) => {
			if (cookie.trim().startsWith(ketchCookieName)) {
				cookieValue = decodeURIComponent(cookie.split('=')[1]);
			}
		});

		return cookieValue;
	}

	/**
	 * get the cookie and parse it into json from base64 string
	 * @returns object that contains the consent details
	 */
	function getSwbCookie() {
		const ketchCookie = getSwbCookieValue();

		try {
			const cookieInfo = window.atob(ketchCookie);
			return JSON.parse(cookieInfo);
		} catch (error) {
			return {};
		}
	}

	/**
	 * Check if the user gave full consent.
	 * @returns If the user gave full consent.
	 */
	function userGaveFullConsent() {
		const userConsent = getSwbCookie();

		if (!userConsent.purposes) {
			return false;
		}

		const purposesKeys = Object.keys(userConsent.purposes);
		let userConsentPrefrences = true;

		// safety check for when the cookie is first intialized
		if (purposesKeys.length === 1) {
			return false;
		}

		purposesKeys.forEach((element) => {
			if (userConsent.purposes[element].allowed === 'false') {
				userConsentPrefrences = false;
			}
		});

		return userConsentPrefrences;
	}

	function waitForWindowObject(ss, lcd) {
		return new Promise((resolve) => {
			function checkObject() {
				if (window.forbes[ss] && window.forbes[lcd]) {
					resolve();
				} else {
					setTimeout(checkObject, 1000);
				}
			}
			checkObject();
		});
	}

	if (window.forbes.isEurope || window.forbes.isChina) {
		if (checkConsentCookieLoaded() && userGaveFullConsent()) {
			loadMedianetHeaderBidding();
			waitForWindowObject('simple-site').then(loadMedianetAd);
		}
	} else {
		loadMedianetHeaderBidding();
		waitForWindowObject('simple-site', 'lastCustomData').then(loadMedianetAd);
	}
})();
</script><script type="text/javascript">LUX=function(){function n(){return Date.now?Date.now():+new Date}var r,e=n(),t=window.performance||{},a=t.timing||{navigationStart:(null===(r=window.LUX)||void 0===r?void 0:r.ns)||e};function o(){return t.now?t.now():n()-a.navigationStart}LUX={ac:[],addData:function(n,r){return LUX.cmd(["addData",n,r])},cmd:function(n){return LUX.ac.push(n)},init:function(){return LUX.cmd(["init"])},mark:function(){for(var n=[],r=0;r<arguments.length;r++)n[r]=arguments[r];if(t.mark)return t.mark.apply(t,n);var e=n[0],a=n[1]||{};void 0===a.startTime&&(a.startTime=o());LUX.cmd(["mark",e,a])},markLoadTime:function(){return LUX.cmd(["markLoadTime",o()])},measure:function(){for(var n=[],r=0;r<arguments.length;r++)n[r]=arguments[r];if(t.measure)return t.measure.apply(t,n);var e,a=n[0],i=n[1],u=n[2];e="object"==typeof i?n[1]:{start:i,end:u};e.duration||e.end||(e.end=o());LUX.cmd(["measure",a,e])},send:function(){return LUX.cmd(["send"])},ns:e};var i=LUX;if(window.LUX_ae=[],window.addEventListener("error",(function(n){window.LUX_ae.push(n)})),window.LUX_al=[],"function"==typeof PerformanceObserver&&"function"==typeof PerformanceLongTaskTiming){var u=new PerformanceObserver((function(n){for(var r=n.getEntries(),e=0;e<r.length;e++)window.LUX_al.push(r[e])}));try{u.observe({type:"longtask"})}catch(n){}}return i}();
LUX = window.LUX || {};
LUX.samplerate = 2;
LUX.label = 'article-desktop-a';
if ('hardwareConcurrency' in navigator)
	LUX.addData('navigator_hardwareConcurrency', navigator.hardwareConcurrency);
if ('connection' in navigator)
	var navigatorConnectionList = [
		'downlink',
		'effectiveType',
		'rtt',
		'saveData',
	]
	navigatorConnectionList.forEach((item) => {
		if (item in navigator.connection) {
			LUX.addData(`navigator_connection_${item}`, navigator.connection[item]);
		}
	});
if ('deviceMemory' in navigator)
	LUX.addData('navigator_deviceMemory', navigator.deviceMemory);
if ('getBattery' in navigator)
	navigator.getBattery().then((battery) => {
		LUX.addData('navigator_getBattery_level', battery.level);
		LUX.addData('navigator_getBattery_charging', battery.charging);
	});
if ('storage' in navigator)
	navigator.storage.estimate().then((estimate) => {
		LUX.addData('navigator_storage_usage', estimate.usage);
		LUX.addData('navigator_storage_quota', estimate.quota);
	});
if(true)
	LUX.addData('ss-bucket', 'A');
	if(true)
		LUX.addData('ss-is-canary', 'false');
if(true)
	LUX.addData('ss-pageType', 'article');
if(true)
	LUX.addData('ss-articleTemplateType', 'standard');
LUX.addData('ss-is-next-js', false);</script><script type="text/javascript" src="https://cdn.speedcurve.com/js/lux.js?id=22432108" async></script><script type="text/javascript">function setupVwo() {
	window._vwo_code = window._vwo_code || (function () {
		var account_id = 707023,
				version = 1.5,
				settings_tolerance = 2000,
				library_tolerance = 2500,
				use_existing_jquery = false,
				is_spa = 1,
				hide_element = 'body',
				hide_element_style = 'opacity:0 !important;filter:alpha(opacity=0) !important;background:none !important',
				/* DO NOT EDIT BELOW THIS LINE */
				f = false, d = document, vwoCodeEl = d.querySelector('#vwoCode'), code = {
					use_existing_jquery: function () {
						return use_existing_jquery
					}, library_tolerance: function () {
						return library_tolerance
					}, hide_element_style: function () {
						return '{' + hide_element_style + '}'
					}, finish: function () {
						if (!f) {
							f = true;
							var e = d.getElementById('_vis_opt_path_hides');
							if (e) e.parentNode.removeChild(e)
						}
					}, finished: function () {
						return f
					}, load: function (e) {
						var t = d.createElement('script');
						t.fetchPriority = 'high';
						t.src = e;
						t.type = 'text/javascript';
						t.onerror = function () {
							_vwo_code.finish()
						};
						d.getElementsByTagName('head')[0].appendChild(t)
					}, getVersion: function () {
						return version
					}, getMatchedCookies: function (e) {
						var t = [];
						if (document.cookie) {
							t = document.cookie.match(e) || []
						}
						return t
					}, getCombinationCookie: function () {
						var e = code.getMatchedCookies(/(?:^|;)\s?(_vis_opt_exp_\d+_combi=[^;$]*)/gi);
						e = e.map(function (e) {
							try {
								var t = decodeURIComponent(e);
								if (!/_vis_opt_exp_\d+_combi=(?:\d+,?)+\s*$/.test(t)) {
									return ''
								}
								return t
							} catch (e) {
								return ''
							}
						});
						var i = [];
						e.forEach(function (e) {
							var t = e.match(/([\d,]+)/g);
							t && i.push(t.join('-'))
						});
						return i.join('|')
					}, init: function () {
						if (d.URL.indexOf('__vwo_disable__') > -1) return;
						window.settings_timer = setTimeout(function () {
							_vwo_code.finish()
						}, settings_tolerance);
						var e = d.createElement('style'),
								t = hide_element ? hide_element + '{' + hide_element_style + '}' : '',
								i = d.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
						e.setAttribute('id', '_vis_opt_path_hides');
						vwoCodeEl && e.setAttribute('nonce', vwoCodeEl.nonce);
						e.setAttribute('type', 'text/css');
						if (e.styleSheet) e.styleSheet.cssText = t; else e.appendChild(d.createTextNode(t));
						i.appendChild(e);
						var n = this.getCombinationCookie();
						this.load('https://dev.visualwebsiteoptimizer.com/j.php?a=' + account_id + '&u=' + encodeURIComponent(d.URL) + '&f=' + +is_spa + '&vn=' + version + (n ? '&c=' + n : ''));
						return settings_timer
					}
				};
		window._vwo_settings_timer = code.init();
		return code;
	}());
}
</script><script id="vwoPreview" type="text/javascript">const urlParams = new URLSearchParams(window.location.search);
// _vis_test_id is set from preview link
let shouldLoadVwo = !!urlParams.get('_vis_test_id');
if(window.name) {
	try {
		const vwoJson = JSON.parse(window.name);
		const previewObj = Object.keys(vwoJson)[0];
		// _vis_preview is set when you click preview button on VWO platform
		if (previewObj.startsWith('_vis_preview')) {
			shouldLoadVwo = true;
		}
	} catch (e) {
		console.warn("invalid vwo preview");
	}
}
if(shouldLoadVwo){
	// set vwo cookie so it loads quicker on next page load (with server check above)
	// 9999 is used to signify very long time, browser will set this to something like 400 days
	document.cookie = "VWO=0.1; expires=Fri, 31 Dec 9999 23:59:59 GMT; path=/";

	setupVwo();

of high-performance textiles and processes for infection prevention.</em></p>
<div class="halfway_hardwall_1"></div><figure class="embed-base image-embed embed-0" role="presentation"><div style="padding-top:66.67%;position:relative" class="image-embed__placeholder"><progressive-image src="https://specials-images.forbesimg.com/imageserve/1248900510/Business-people-return-back-to-work-after-covid-19-pandemic/960x0.jpg?fit=scale" alt="Business people return back to work after covid-19 pandemic" data-height="4480" data-width="6720"></progressive-image></div><figcaption><p class="color-body light-text"> </p><small class="color-body light-text">Getty</small></figcaption></figure>
<div class="article_paragraph_2"></div>
<p>With Covid-19 vaccinations now available to the masses, many U.S. workers are facing a return to the office. However, I expect much to be different in the new office environment, including the previously common culture of powering through illnesses as a badge of honor, eating at desks, dealing with grimy kitchens and piling into open floor plans. Additionally, many workers will be on hybrid schedules, spending part of their time in the office and the rest working from home. This means theyâ€™ll share work spaces with colleagues, possibly complete strangers, who are at the office when theyâ€™re working remotely.</p>
<div class="halfway_hardwall_2"></div>
<p>In this new normal, businesses large and small â€” as well as facilities that house them â€” must be prepared to adopt elevated hygiene protocols, including when to stay home, how to cover a cough or sneeze and how to safely and effectively clean and disinfect communal and frequently used surfaces (e.g., workstations, water fountains, handles, elevator panels and bathrooms).</p>
<div class="halfway_hardwall_3"></div>
<div class="vestpocket" vest-pocket=""></div>
<p><strong>Looking Beyond The Pandemic</strong></p>
<div class="halfway_hardwall_4"></div>
<p>This isnâ€™t just a pandemic issue. While Covid-19 heightened the worldâ€™s attention on infection prevention, focusing singularly on eliminating SARS-CoV-2 is myopic. Why? Before the pandemic, employee illness accounted for billions of dollars lost annually in the U.S. In 2018, experts estimated that the flu costs the U.S. more than $10 billion annually. And, depending on the severity of the season, anywhere between <a href="https://www.marketwatch.com/story/this-is-how-much-this-years-flu-season-could-cost-you-2018-01-09" target="_blank" class="color-link" title="https://www.marketwatch.com/story/this-is-how-much-this-years-flu-season-could-cost-you-2018-01-09" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" data-ga-track="ExternalLink:https://www.marketwatch.com/story/this-is-how-much-this-years-flu-season-could-cost-you-2018-01-09" aria-label="$7 billion to $15 billion">$7 billion to $15 billion</a> can be lost in productivity and sick days. A 2003 study found that non-flu-related viral respiratory tract infections cost U.S. companies approximately <a href="https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12588210/" target="_blank" class="color-link" title="https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12588210/" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" data-ga-track="ExternalLink:https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12588210/" aria-label="$40 billion">$40 billion</a> per year.</p><fbs-ad position="inread" progressive="" ad-id="article-0-inread" aria-hidden="true" role="presentation"></fbs-ad>
<p>As the CEO and founder of a company that creates high-performance textiles for infection prevention, I believe many of the infection prevention processes implemented and adhered to during the pandemic should be maintained on an ongoing basis. Mitigating the impact of the annual flu season on office productivity, not to mention the burden on health care, is an economically sound strategy.</p>

<p>By taking a commonsense approach, business leaders and facility managers can ensure their employees and tenants feel as safe as possible when they return to the office while reaping rewards such as increased productivity and employee loyalty. Below are steps you can take:</p>
<div class="article_paragraph_7"></div>
<p><strong>1. Schedule regular professional cleanings with reputable firms.</strong> Consider partnering with professional cleaning organizations that adhere to <a href="https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/disinfecting-building-facility.html" target="_blank" class="color-link" title="https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/disinfecting-building-facility.html" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" data-ga-track="ExternalLink:https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/disinfecting-building-facility.html" aria-label="CDC guidelines">CDC guidelines</a> and invest in the regular training of their workforces. Make sure you understand their processes and procedures, products used for cleaning and disinfecting and the amount of time allotted. Youâ€™ll want to discuss:</p>

<p>â€¢ The disinfectant used to ensure it is safe, sustainable and effective against the broadest range of organisms, including bacteria, fungi, viruses and spores. Examples of pathogens that can impact an office environment are norovirus, common influenza, Clostridioides difficile (known as C. diff) and MRSA. Hundreds of products are listed on the EPAâ€™s <a href="https://www.epa.gov/coronavirus/about-list-n-disinfectants-coronavirus-covid-19-0" target="_blank" class="color-link" title="https://www.epa.gov/coronavirus/about-list-n-disinfectants-coronavirus-covid-19-0" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" data-ga-track="ExternalLink:https://www.epa.gov/coronavirus/about-list-n-disinfectants-coronavirus-covid-19-0" aria-label="List N">List N</a> for Covid-19, but very few are also listed on the EPAâ€™s <a href="https://www.epa.gov/pesticide-registration/list-k-epas-registered-antimicrobial-products-effective-against-clostridium" target="_blank" class="color-link" title="https://www.epa.gov/pesticide-registration/list-k-epas-registered-antimicrobial-products-effective-against-clostridium" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" data-ga-track="ExternalLink:https://www.epa.gov/pesticide-registration/list-k-epas-registered-antimicrobial-products-effective-against-clostridium" aria-label="List K">List K</a> for C. diff.</p>
<p>â€¢ The plan for what and when to clean and disinfect.</p>
<p>â€¢ A multi-modal approach to engaging all employees.</p>
<p>â€¢ Specifics around training and recognition programs. Cleaners must understand the science behind cleaning and disinfection in order to perform optimally. Iâ€™ve found recognition boosts employee loyalty and incentivizes them to maintain high standards of performance.</p>
<p><strong>2. Conduct basic employee cleaning and disinfection training.</strong> Even with professional cleaners in place, in the new normal, many employees no doubt will want to take control of cleaning and disinfecting frequently touched surfaces throughout their days. A little training goes a long way in making sure your workforce is armed with the facts about how to prevent the spread of germs:</p>
<p>â€¢ Explain the difference between cleaning and disinfection.</p>
<p>â€¢ Show employees how and when to clean frequently touched surfaces and common areas.</p>
<p>â€¢ Focus on frequently touched surfaces, such as workstations (e.g., keyboard, mouse, computer, desk surface, phone), printers and fax machines, and kitchens (e.g., microwave, coffee machine, toaster, refrigerator handles).</p>
<p>â€¢ Supply employees with color-coded products for cleaning each area to ensure no cross-contamination.</p>
<p>â€¢ Provide employees with access to safe disinfectants and appropriate guidelines for how and when they should be used (i.e., after thoroughly cleaning an area).</p>
<p><strong>3. Keep it sustainable.</strong> I recommend staying away from single-use, disposable wipes and harsh chemicals. According to the <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/21/smarter-living/disposable-cleaning-products-alternatives.html" target="_blank" class="color-link" title="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/21/smarter-living/disposable-cleaning-products-alternatives.html" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" data-ga-track="ExternalLink:https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/21/smarter-living/disposable-cleaning-products-alternatives.html" aria-label="New York Times"><em data-ga-track="ExternalLink:https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/21/smarter-living/disposable-cleaning-products-alternatives.html">New York Times</em></a>, â€œDisposable cleaning products are often more expensive and less effective than the reusable products they replace.â€ When searching for alternatives, keep the following in mind:</p>
<p>â€¢ <a href="https://www.osha.gov/sites/default/files/publications/OSHA3512.pdf" target="_blank" class="color-link" title="https://www.osha.gov/sites/default/files/publications/OSHA3512.pdf" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" data-ga-track="ExternalLink:https://www.osha.gov/sites/default/files/publications/OSHA3512.pdf" aria-label="OSHA">OSHA</a> recommends using microfiber mops, cloths and dusters to help minimize chemical use.</p>
<p>â€¢ When it comes to cleaning chemicals, some can be hazardous, causing problems ranging from rashes on the skin to coughing and asthma. This is why I also suggest referring to a helpful <a href="https://www.health.state.mn.us/communities/environment/risk/docs/guidance/cleaners.pdf" target="_blank" class="color-link" title="https://www.health.state.mn.us/communities/environment/risk/docs/guidance/cleaners.pdf" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" data-ga-track="ExternalLink:https://www.health.state.mn.us/communities/environment/risk/docs/guidance/cleaners.pdf" aria-label="guide">guide</a> for evaluating safe cleaners, disinfectants and sanitizers.</p>
<p><strong>4. Update and communicate your sick policy and basic hygiene reminders. </strong>Gone are the days of powering through coughs, colds and the flu at the office. If employees are able, allow them to work remotely from home. If they canâ€™t, allow them to take time off. As an employer, be sure you also:</p>
<p>â€¢ Include guidelines on whether mask wearing will be required (and if oneâ€™s vaccination status affects this) and what to do if employees feel sick.</p>
<p>â€¢ Post signage throughout the office regarding how and when to wash hands, when to stay home (e.g., if your employee has a fever over a certain temperature, cough, chills, etc.) and whether employees need to keep distance from co-workers.</p>
<p>â€¢ Create communications from leadership for the first few weeks in the office to reinforce new policies. Reiterate each quarter.</p>
<p>â€¢ Engage employees and encourage feedback.</p>
<p>Thereâ€™s no doubt about it: The return to the office will be another transition for many of us. However, by leveraging these best practices, business and facility leaders can ensure it is as smooth as possible. This upfront investment of time and resources will not only ensure employee loyalty and goodwill but also could save businesses significant money down the line in terms of increased productivity.</p><hr class="embed-base rule-embed color-accent border-solid weight-light">

readabilityObject.title: The Return To The Office: Best Practices For Helping Employees Feel Safe
readabilityObject.content:
CEO and Founder of UMF Corporation, a leader in the R&D of high-performance textiles and processes for infection prevention.

With Covid-19 vaccinations now available to the masses, many U.S. workers are facing a return to the office. However, I expect much to be different in the new office environment, including the previously common culture of powering through illnesses as a badge of honor, eating at desks, dealing with grimy kitchens and piling into open floor plans. Additionally, many workers will be on hybrid schedules, spending part of their time in the office and the rest working from home. This means theyâ€™ll share work spaces with colleagues, possibly complete strangers, who are at the office when theyâ€™re working remotely.

In this new normal, businesses large and small â€” as well as facilities that house them â€” must be prepared to adopt elevated hygiene protocols, including when to stay home, how to cover a cough or sneeze and how to safely and effectively clean and disinfect communal and frequently used surfaces (e.g., workstations, water fountains, handles, elevator panels and bathrooms).

Looking Beyond The Pandemic

This isnâ€™t just a pandemic issue. While Covid-19 heightened the worldâ€™s attention on infection prevention, focusing singularly on eliminating SARS-CoV-2 is myopic. Why? Before the pandemic, employee illness accounted for billions of dollars lost annually in the U.S. In 2018, experts estimated that the flu costs the U.S. more than $10 billion annually. And, depending on the severity of the season, anywhere between $7 billion to $15 billion can be lost in productivity and sick days. A 2003 study found that non-flu-related viral respiratory tract infections cost U.S. companies approximately $40 billion per year.

As the CEO and founder of a company that creates high-performance textiles for infection prevention, I believe many of the infection prevention processes implemented and adhered to during the pandemic should be maintained on an ongoing basis. Mitigating the impact of the annual flu season on office productivity, not to mention the burden on health care, is an economically sound strategy.

By taking a commonsense approach, business leaders and facility managers can ensure their employees and tenants feel as safe as possible when they return to the office while reaping rewards such as increased productivity and employee loyalty. Below are steps you can take:

1. Schedule regular professional cleanings with reputable firms. Consider partnering with professional cleaning organizations that adhere to CDC guidelines and invest in the regular training of their workforces. Make sure you understand their processes and procedures, products used for cleaning and disinfecting and the amount of time allotted. Youâ€™ll want to discuss:

â€¢ The disinfectant used to ensure it is safe, sustainable and effective against the broadest range of organisms, including bacteria, fungi, viruses and spores. Examples of pathogens that can impact an office environment are norovirus, common influenza, Clostridioides difficile (known as C. diff) and MRSA. Hundreds of products are listed on the EPAâ€™s List N for Covid-19, but very few are also listed on the EPAâ€™s List K for C. diff.

â€¢ The plan for what and when to clean and disinfect.

â€¢ A multi-modal approach to engaging all employees.

â€¢ Specifics around training and recognition programs. Cleaners must understand the science behind cleaning and disinfection in order to perform optimally. Iâ€™ve found recognition boosts employee loyalty and incentivizes them to maintain high standards of performance.

2. Conduct basic employee cleaning and disinfection training. Even with professional cleaners in place, in the new normal, many employees no doubt will want to take control of cleaning and disinfecting frequently touched surfaces throughout their days. A little training goes a long way in making sure your workforce is armed with the facts about how to prevent the spread of germs:

â€¢ Explain the difference between cleaning and disinfection.

â€¢ Show employees how and when to clean frequently touched surfaces and common areas.

â€¢ Focus on frequently touched surfaces, such as workstations (e.g., keyboard, mouse, computer, desk surface, phone), printers and fax machines, and kitchens (e.g., microwave, coffee machine, toaster, refrigerator handles).

â€¢ Supply employees with color-coded products for cleaning each area to ensure no cross-contamination.

â€¢ Provide employees with access to safe disinfectants and appropriate guidelines for how and when they should be used (i.e., after thoroughly cleaning an area).

3. Keep it sustainable. I recommend staying away from single-use, disposable wipes and harsh chemicals. According to the New York Times, â€œDisposable cleaning products are often more expensive and less effective than the reusable products they replace.â€ When searching for alternatives, keep the following in mind:

â€¢ OSHA recommends using microfiber mops, cloths and dusters to help minimize chemical use.

â€¢ When it comes to cleaning chemicals, some can be hazardous, causing problems ranging from rashes on the skin to coughing and asthma. This is why I also suggest referring to a helpful guide for evaluating safe cleaners, disinfectants and sanitizers.

4. Update and communicate your sick policy and basic hygiene reminders. Gone are the days of powering through coughs, colds and the flu at the office. If employees are able, allow them to work remotely from home. If they canâ€™t, allow them to take time off. As an employer, be sure you also:

â€¢ Include guidelines on whether mask wearing will be required (and if oneâ€™s vaccination status affects this) and what to do if employees feel sick.

â€¢ Post signage throughout the office regarding how and when to wash hands, when to stay home (e.g., if your employee has a fever over a certain temperature, cough, chills, etc.) and whether employees need to keep distance from co-workers.

â€¢ Create communications from leadership for the first few weeks in the office to reinforce new policies. Reiterate each quarter.

â€¢ Engage employees and encourage feedback.

Thereâ€™s no doubt about it: The return to the office will be another transition for many of us. However, by leveraging these best practices, business and facility leaders can ensure it is as smooth as possible. This upfront investment of time and resources will not only ensure employee loyalty and goodwill but also could save businesses significant money down the line in terms of increased productivity.

Forbes Business Council is the foremost growth and networking organization for business owners and leaders. Do I qualify?
